audire: Latin verb meaning 'to hear'. The name of this application.
algorithm: A process or set of rules to be followed in calculations or other problem-solving operations.
application: A program or piece of software designed and written to fulfill a particular purpose of the user.
audio: Sound, especially when recorded, transmitted, or reproduced.
book: A written or printed work consisting of pages glued or sewn together along one side and bound in covers.
code: A system of words, letters, figures, or other symbols substituted for other words, letters, etc., especially for secrecy.
compiler: A program that converts instructions into a machine-code or lower-level form so that they can be read and executed by a computer.
computer: An electronic device for storing and processing data.
data: Facts and statistics collected together for reference or analysis.
database: A structured set of data held in a computer, especially one that is accessible in various ways.
debug: Identify and remove errors from (computer hardware or software).
developer: A person or thing that develops something.
digital: Expressed as series of the digits 0 and 1, typically represented by values of a physical quantity such as voltage or magnetic polarization.
flutter: An open-source UI software development kit created by Google.
function: A basic task of a computer, especially one that corresponds to a single instruction from the user.
hardware: The machines, wiring, and other physical components of a computer or other electronic system.
interface: A point where two systems, subjects, organizations, etc., meet and interact.
internet: A global computer network providing a variety of information and communication facilities.
java: A general-purpose computer-programming language that is concurrent, class-based, object-oriented, and specifically designed to have as few implementation dependencies as possible.
library: A collection of precompiled routines that a program can use.
memory: The faculty by which the mind stores and remembers information.
mobile: Able to move or be moved freely or easily.
network: A group or system of interconnected people or things.
offline: Not connected to a computer or computer network.
online: Controlled by or connected to another computer or to a network.
pdf: Portable Document Format, a file format that provides an electronic image of text or text and graphics.
program: Provide (a computer or other machine) with coded instructions for the automatic performance of a task.
protocol: The official procedure or system of rules governing affairs of state or diplomatic occasions.
read: Look at and comprehend the meaning of (written or printed matter) by mentally interpreting the characters or symbols of which it is composed.
screen: A fixed or movable upright partition used to divide a room, to give shelter from drafts or heat, or to provide concealment.
search: Try to find something by looking or otherwise seeking carefully and thoroughly.
server: A computer or computer program that manages access to a centralized resource or service in a network.
software: The programs and other operating information used by a computer.
storage: The action or method of storing something for future use.
syntax: The arrangement of words and phrases to create well-formed sentences in a language.
system: A set of connected things or parts forming a complex whole.
technology: The application of scientific knowledge for practical purposes.
terminal: A device at which a user enters data or commands for a computer system and displays the received output.
user: A person who uses or operates something, especially a computer or other machine.
variable: Not consistent or having a fixed pattern; liable to change.
virtual: Almost or nearly as described, but not completely or according to strict definition.
voice: The sound produced in a person's larynx and uttered through the mouth, as speech or song.
web: A complex system of interconnected elements.
wireless: Using radio, microwaves, etc. (as opposed to wires or cables) to transmit signals.
zambia: A landlocked country in southern Africa.
